title: PEAK SCHOLARSHIP
description:
1/2/26
Frontier Community College and Olney Central College are pleased to announce the Kenton Peak Scholarship, a $1,000 annual award supporting students pursuing para-medical fields, emergency medical response, and other healthcare-related programs.
The Kenton Peak Scholarship can be awarded to either an incoming freshman or a returning sophomore. Â Funds may be used for tuition, textbooks, fees, and other program-related expenses, helping students prepare for vital roles as future first responders and healthcare providers.
To be eligible, applicants must, be enrolled in a para-medical, EM responder, or healthcare program at FCC or OCC, maintain a minimum 2.5 GPA, take an active role in emergency preparedness, and plan to serve as an EMT or healthcare provider after graduation.
The application deadline for the Kenton Peak Scholarship is February 27th.
For more information or to apply, visit https://iecc.edu/fcc/admissions-aid/scholarships or contact FCC or OCC Student Services.

title: ğŸ¦ GROCERY TAX GONE?
description:
1/2/26
Illinoisâ€™ statewide 1% grocery tax went away yesterday, although many people continue to pay it at the local level.
Data compiled by the Illinois Municipal League shows that 656 municipalities, a little more than half of the stateâ€™s municipalities, have passed an ordinance establishing their own grocery tax. Â Those communities are home to 7.2 million people, or 56.5% of the stateâ€™s population. Â Three counties, Washington, Wabash and Moultrie have also approved countywide grocery taxes.Â  In Clay County, Flora, Louisville and Clay City have all passed a 1% grocery tax.
Governor JB Pritzker signed a bill in 2024 eliminating the 1% statewide grocery tax, which he touted as a measure to ease residentsâ€™ tax burden. Â But because the revenue from the state grocery tax went to municipal governments, rather than state coffers, the measure allowed local governments to levy their own 1% tax via ordinance, rather than a referendum to voters.

title: ğŸ¦ RURAL HEALTHCARE AWARD
description:
1/2/26
Illinois has been awarded $193,418,216 per year for five years through the $50 billion federal Rural Healthcare Transformation Program (RHTP) fund, which will be utilized to expand equitable access to healthcare and to eliminate barriers to care that many residents of rural communities face. Â All 50 states applied for the RHTP funding, and a total of $10 billion will be available each year over five years, beginning in fiscal year 2026.
While this funding will provide support to improve healthcare access in rural Illinois communities, it will be far from enough to counteract the cuts imposed to the Medicaid program through various provisions in the Trump Administrationâ€™s budget bill. Â According to an estimate from KFF, the Trump Administrationâ€™s budget bill is expected to cut $137 billion from rural healthcare providers nationally, nearly three times the $50 billion allocated in the fund.
The Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services (HFS), in strategic partnership with its sister agencies and interested parties, utilized the federal Centers for Medicare & Medicaidâ€™s (CMS) five strategic goals from the RHTP Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO), to develop a comprehensive plan to strengthen Illinoisâ€™ rural healthcare system for the future. Â The plan outlines a vision built on three key categories of initiatives designed to incentivize health system transformation and create regional partnerships, increase the use of technology and mobile health services, and expand the rural healthcare workforce within the state.
Roughly 1.9 million people, or 15% of Illinoisâ€™ population, live in rural areas of the state. Â RHTP funding will be directed to entities that serve these individuals in rural census tracts across Illinois. Â Eighty-five counties, or more than two thirds of the counties in the state, include these types of census tracts as designated by the federal Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA). Â Within this framework, particular attention will be paid to sub-populations, such as individuals living with chronic disease and those with mental health conditions.
HFS will continue engaging with stakeholders on next steps regarding funding distribution. Â Staff planning and implementation are underway in partnership with other state agencies as well as with federal CMS.

title: FARM PAYMENTS ANNOUNCED
description:
1/2/26
Farmers are now learning how much aid they can expect to receive from a $12 billion package that President Donald Trump announced earlier this month.
The US Department of Agriculture released the figures on Wednesday for how much aid per acre farmers can plan on for each row crop. Â The details arrived after most farmers had already met with their bankers to arrange financing for next yearâ€™s crops and placed orders for the seed and fertilizer they would need. Â But officials have promised that the payments should arrive by the end of February.
Soybean farmers have been hit especially hard by Trumpâ€™s trade war with China, which stopped buying any American crops after Trump announced his tariffs this spring. Â China is the worldâ€™s largest buyer of soybeans. This aid package is expected to help farmers weather the trade disruptions until China buys more soybeans under an agreement announced in October and until provisions of Trumpâ€™s massive budget bill take effect later this year.
Soybean farmers will get $30.88 per acre while corn farmers will receive $44.36 per acre. Â Another crop hit hard when China stopped buying was sorghum, and those farmers will get $48.11 per acre. Â The amounts are based on a USDA formula on the cost of production.
But farmers say the aid wonâ€™t solve all their problems as they continue to deal with the soaring costs of fertilizer, seeds and labor that make it hard to turn a profit right now. Â Some agricultural trade groups have said they worry that thousands of farmers could go out of business, but others have said they believe most farmers have the financial resources and equity needed to survive.
Kentucky soybean farmer Caleb Ragland, who was president of the American Soybean Association until recently, said the aid is â€œa Band-Aid on a deep wound. We need competition and opportunities in the market to make our future brighter.â€
The President of the National Corn Growers Association Jed Bower also urged the Trump administration to focus on cultivating additional uses for their crops. Â Farmers will benefit from having more buyers whether it is for ethanol and animal feed at home or for international markets.
â€œCorn growers have been sounding the alarm about the fact that farmers have been faced with multiple consecutive years of low corn prices and high input costs,â€ Bower said. Â â€œWhile this financial assistance is helpful and welcomed, we urgently need the administration and Congress to develop markets in the United States and abroad that will provide growers with more long-term economic certainty.â€
Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said that is the goal and promised to continue working to open new markets while strengthening the safety net for farmers.
Minnesota Soybean Growers Association President Darin Johnson said the aid number for soybeans fell short of what farmers had been hoping for, so more help could be needed, though this package will help.
Most farmers remain steadfast supporters of Trump even after the disruptions caused by the trade war. Â They generally support many of his other policies and believe they will get a better trade deal in the end.
These aid payments will add up to $11 billion for row crop farmers who raise corn, soybeans, wheat, sorghum and other crops. Â Another $1 billion has been set aside for specialty crops and sugar, but the administration hasnâ€™t released any details of aid for those crops.
The aid payments will be capped at $155,000 per farmer or entity, and only farms that make less than $900,000 in adjusted gross income will be eligible.
The USDA says the average size of the 1.88 million farms nationwide was 466 acres last year. Â Still, many farmers are much larger than that as larger operations have continued to buy up neighboring farms over time.
